subject: Home & DIY
title: Mushroom-Based Materials
description: A fast breakdown of Mushroom-Based Materials for builders.

hook.text: Myceliumâ€”the root network of mushroomsâ€”can be grown into solid boards that replace foam, plastic, and even leather.

buildup.text: Researchers feed farm waste to mycelium in molds. In days, the fungal threads bind the material into a solid shape.

discovery.text: The resulting material is lightweight, fire-resistant, and fully compostable. It decomposes in soil within 45 days.

twist.text: IKEA is testing mycelium packaging as a replacement for styrofoam. Furniture cores could be next.

climax.text: Imagine furniture that grows in a week, serves for years, and returns to soil when you're done. The biology works.

punchline.text: Furniture grown from mushrooms, composted back to earth.

quiz.question: How is mycelium turned into a solid building material?
options: It grows through agricultural waste in molds, binding it into shape
It's compressed under extreme pressure like plywood
It's chemically treated to harden like resin
